div.p: Greetings. Reverend father in Christ, you would not listen as eagerly as I would diligently write, if I had discovered anything about the council and Italian affairs; but now all is silent, and for these eight days, letters from friends have completely ceased, which I do not doubt are on their way.
I hear from trustworthy men that the fathers of Trent are sparing no effort to strengthen the tyranny of the papacy.
There are those who affirm that Cardinal Lorraine, along with another, I know not whom, has flown to Rome; the reason for the journey is not given.

We all confess that we owe you much, as you do not cease to inform us about French and German affairs; indeed, I am often ashamed of myself, as I have nothing to offer in return, yet I continually draw upon your resources.
I return all your belongings in good faith and offer the greatest thanks I can; I will make an effort to write something certain shortly.
I write this now to excuse my silence to you with some honest reason.
Farewell, reverend father, with all your family, as happily and as long as possible.
I have included these letters with yours so that they would not be lost alone, and I ask, by your singular kindness, that you ensure they are delivered to Mr. Collin.
To the most distinguished man, equipped with all kinds of learning and piety, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and father in Christ, uniquely revered.
